concepts.title: What Is Yoga and Biomimicry
concepts.content: Yoga is an ancient Indian physical, mental, and spiritual discipline. It originated in India thousands of years ago and is now practised by millions worldwide. International Yoga Day is celebrated on 21 June every year since 2015, following India's proposal at the United Nations. Biomimicry is the concept of solving human problems by observing and imitating nature's solutions ‚Äî animal yoga poses are an example of biomimicry.

examples.text: Yoga originated in India thousands of years ago
International Yoga Day: 21 June ‚Äî celebrated worldwide
Biomimicry: yoga poses inspired by animal postures
Ancient Indian sages observed animals and developed asanas

keyPoints: Yoga is an ancient Indian physical, mental, and spiritual practice
International Yoga Day: 21 June (since 2015)
India proposed International Yoga Day at the United Nations
Biomimicry: solving human problems by imitating nature's solutions
Many yoga asanas are named after and inspired by animals
concepts.funFact: Prime Minister Narendra Modi proposed International Yoga Day at the UN in 2014, and 177 countries co-sponsored it. It was passed unanimously ‚Äî the largest ever co-sponsorship of a UN resolution!

concepts.title: Bhujangasana ‚Äî The Cobra Pose
concepts.content: Bhujangasana (cobra pose) is inspired by the way a cobra raises its hood. To do this pose, you lie on your stomach, place your palms on the floor near your chest, and gently lift your head and chest ‚Äî like a cobra raising its head. This pose strengthens the back, stretches the spine, and improves posture. 'Bhujanga' means cobra in Sanskrit.

examples.text: Inspired by a cobra raising its hood ‚Äî Bhujanga means cobra in Sanskrit
Strengthens the back muscles and spine
Improves posture and reduces back pain
Lie on stomach, palms flat, and gently raise head and chest

keyPoints: Bhujangasana = cobra pose (Bhujanga = cobra in Sanskrit)
Inspired by the way a cobra raises its hood
Lie on stomach, lift head and chest like a cobra
Benefits: strengthens back, stretches spine, improves posture
Good for students who sit for long hours studying
concepts.funFact: The cobra is one of India's most recognisable animals. The King Cobra is found in the Western Ghats of Maharashtra and is the world's longest venomous snake. Bhujangasana pays homage to its graceful posture!

concepts.title: Simhasana (Lion) and Marjaryasana (Cat)
concepts.content: Simhasana (lion pose) involves kneeling, leaning forward slightly, stretching your tongue out as far as possible, and letting out a roar. This pose exercises the throat, tongue, and facial muscles, and helps release tension. Marjaryasana (cat pose) involves going on all fours and alternately arching and rounding the spine ‚Äî like a cat stretching. It improves spinal flexibility and relieves back tension.

examples.text: Simhasana: kneel, lean forward, stretch tongue out and ROAR!
Benefits: exercises face, throat, tongue; releases tension
Marjaryasana: on all fours, arch spine up then curve down ‚Äî like a cat
Benefits: improves spinal flexibility and relieves back pain

keyPoints: Simhasana = lion pose (Simha = lion in Sanskrit)
Kneel, lean forward, stretch tongue out, and roar like a lion
Benefits of Simhasana: exercises face and throat, releases tension
Marjaryasana = cat pose (Marjara = cat in Sanskrit)
Benefits of Marjaryasana: improves spine flexibility, relieves back tension
concepts.funFact: Cats do a full body stretch every time they wake up ‚Äî this is exactly what Marjaryasana imitates! Scientists now know this cat stretch prevents muscle injuries and improves flexibility!

concepts.title: Garudasana (Eagle) and Ustrasana (Camel)
concepts.content: Garudasana (eagle pose) involves balancing on one leg with the other leg wrapped around it, and both arms entwined. It improves balance, concentration, and strengthens leg muscles. Ustrasana (camel pose) involves kneeling and bending backwards to touch your heels, opening the chest and shoulders. It stretches the front of the body and improves posture.

examples.text: Garudasana: balance on one leg, other leg wrapped around ‚Äî like an eagle perching
Garudasana benefits: improves balance and concentration
Ustrasana: kneel and bend back to touch heels ‚Äî like a camel's hump shape
Ustrasana benefits: opens chest and shoulders, improves posture

keyPoints: Garudasana = eagle pose (Garuda = eagle in Sanskrit ‚Äî Vishnu's vehicle)
Stand on one leg with other leg and arms entwined for balance
Benefits of Garudasana: improves balance, concentration, leg strength
Ustrasana = camel pose (Ustra = camel in Sanskrit)
Kneel and bend backwards to touch heels ‚Äî opens chest and shoulders
concepts.funFact: Garuda (the eagle) is the divine vehicle (vahana) of Lord Vishnu in Hindu mythology! Garudasana is named after this sacred bird ‚Äî so practicing this pose has a spiritual dimension too.

concepts.title: Conjunctions and Interjections
concepts.content: Conjunctions are words that join two words, phrases, or sentences. Common conjunctions: and, but, or, if, because, when. Interjections are words that express strong feelings or emotions, usually followed by an exclamation mark. Common interjections: Hurrah! (joy), Ouch! (pain), Wow! (surprise), Bravo! (appreciation), Alas! (sorrow).

examples.text: Conjunction 'and': Yoga is healthy and fun.
Conjunction 'but': I tried yoga, but it was difficult.
Interjection 'Hurrah!': Hurrah! We won the match!
Interjection 'Wow!': Wow! What a beautiful pose!

keyPoints: Conjunctions: words that join words, phrases, or sentences
Common conjunctions: and, but, or, if, because, when
Interjections: words expressing strong emotions, followed by !
Hurrah! = joy; Ouch! = pain; Wow! = surprise; Alas! = sorrow
Interjections stand alone or at the start of a sentence
concepts.funFact: Interjections are used very often in Indian languages! In Marathi: 'Shabba!' (well done!), 'Are va!' (wow!), 'Hai!' (oh no!) ‚Äî just like English interjections, they express feeling instantly!

test.question: When is International Yoga Day celebrated?
test.explanation: International Yoga Day is celebrated on 21 June every year since 2015. India proposed this day at the United Nations.

test.question: What does 'biomimicry' mean?
options: Solving human problems by imitating nature's solutions
A type of dance inspired by animals
A medicine made from animal products
A way of painting pictures of animals
test.explanation: Biomimicry means solving human problems by observing and imitating solutions found in nature. Animal yoga poses are an example.

test.question: What does 'Bhujanga' mean in Sanskrit?
test.explanation: Bhujanga means cobra in Sanskrit. Bhujangasana is the cobra pose, inspired by the way a cobra raises its hood.

test.question: What are the benefits of Bhujangasana (cobra pose)?
options: Strengthens the back and stretches the spine
test.explanation: Bhujangasana (cobra pose) strengthens the back muscles and stretches the spine. It is especially beneficial for people who sit for long hours.

test.question: What do you do in Simhasana (lion pose)?
options: Kneel, lean forward, stretch tongue out, and roar
Stand on one leg with arms entwined
Lie on stomach and raise head and chest
Kneel and bend backwards to touch heels
test.explanation: In Simhasana (lion pose), you kneel, lean forward slightly, stretch your tongue out as far as possible, and let out a roar like a lion.

test.question: What is the benefit of Garudasana (eagle pose)?
test.explanation: Garudasana (eagle pose) improves balance, concentration, and strengthens the legs. You balance on one leg with the other wrapped around it.

test.question: In which yoga pose do you kneel and bend backwards to touch your heels?
test.explanation: In Ustrasana (camel pose), you kneel and bend backwards to touch your heels, opening the chest and shoulders.

test.question: Which word is a conjunction?
test.explanation: 'Because' is a conjunction ‚Äî it joins two clauses and shows reason. 'Hurrah' and 'Ouch' are interjections.

test.question: Which sentence contains an interjection?
options: Wow! That was an amazing yoga performance!
Yoga is both healthy and fun.
We do yoga because it is good for us.
If you practise daily, you will improve.
test.explanation: 'Wow!' is an interjection expressing strong surprise and admiration. Interjections express emotions and are usually followed by an exclamation mark.

test.question: Which conjunction would best fill the blank: 'Yoga is good for the body _____ the mind.'?
test.explanation: 'And' is the correct conjunction here ‚Äî it joins two things (body and mind) that go together. 'And' is used to add information.

keyConcepts: Yoga is an ancient Indian physical, mental, and spiritual discipline
Biomimicry: solving human problems by imitating nature
Simhasana (lion): exercises face, throat, tongue; releases tension
Conjunctions: and, but, or, if, because, when ‚Äî join words/clauses
Interjections: Hurrah!, Ouch!, Wow!, Bravo! ‚Äî express strong emotions
commonMisconceptions: Yoga is only about physical exercise ‚Äî FALSE (it is physical, mental, and spiritual)
Interjections must always be at the start of a sentence ‚Äî NOT ALWAYS (they can appear in other positions)
Conjunctions and prepositions are the same ‚Äî FALSE (conjunctions join; prepositions show relationships between nouns)
